etymologies: Middle English (as a verb): from Anglo-Norman French escalder, from late Latin excaldare, from Latin ex- ‘thoroughly’ + calidus ‘hot’. The noun dates from the early 17th century

definitions: injure with very hot liquid or steam
shortDefinitions: injure with very hot liquid or steam

definitions: heat (milk or other liquid) to near boiling point

examples.text: scald the milk with the citrus zest

shortDefinitions: heat milk or other liquid to near boiling point

definitions: immerse (something) briefly in boiling water for various purposes, such as to facilitate the removal of skin from fruit or to preserve meat

examples.text: a medium sliced tomato, scalded in water to remove its skin

shortDefinitions: immerse something briefly in boiling water for various purposes

definitions: cause to feel a searing sensation like that of boiling water on skin
shortDefinitions: cause to feel searing sensation like that of boiling water on skin

definitions: a burn or other injury caused by hot liquid or steam.
shortDefinitions: burn or other injury caused by hot liquid or steam

definitions: any of a number of plant diseases that produce a similar effect to that of scalding, especially a disease of fruit marked by browning and caused by excessive sunlight, bad storage conditions, or atmospheric pollution.
shortDefinitions: several plant diseases that produce similar effect to that of scalding
